article.title: Duty and Tax Calculation Methods
article.summary: See examples of the two generally accepted methods for calculating duty rates: CIF and FOB.
article.content:
â€‹There are two generally accepted methods for calculating duty rates: CIF and FOB. Most countries use the CIF method. Some exceptions may apply. VAT (Value Added Taxes) are generally applied on the CIF or FOB + Duty value. The figures used below are forexample only. For questions about duty and tax calculation call 1-800-USA-TRAD(E).

CIF (Cost, Insurance, Freight)

A pricing term indicating that the cost of goods, insurance, and freight are included in the quoted price. Duty is calculated by adding all costs together. See below for example.*

FOB (Free on Board)

A pricing term indicating that the cost of the goods, including all transportation and insurance costs from the manufacturer to the port of departure, as well as the costs of loading the vessel, are included in the quoted price. It should be noted that the Incoterm FOB applies only to shipments via sea or inland waterway transport. For the purpose of calculating duties and taxes for international shipments, the term FOB generally applies to the commercial invoice value and does not include the cost of shipping and insurance.
